questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The children are playing in the garden.'
questions.explanation: This is a simple sentence with one subject (children) and one finite verb (are playing).

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'She went to the market, and she bought some vegetables.'
questions.explanation: This is a compound sentence with two independent clauses joined by the coordinating conjunction 'and'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'When the rain stopped, we went outside.'
questions.explanation: This is a complex sentence with a subordinate clause (When the rain stopped) and a main clause (we went outside).

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Neither Rahul nor his friends attended the party.'
questions.explanation: This is a simple sentence with a compound subject but only one finite verb (attended).

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The teacher entered the class, and the students stood up.'
questions.explanation: Two independent clauses joined by the coordinating conjunction 'and'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Although he was tired, he finished his homework.'
questions.explanation: Complex sentence with subordinate clause (Although he was tired) and main clause.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Besides being intelligent, she is also very hardworking.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with a participial phrase (Besides being intelligent).

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'I like tea, but my sister prefers coffee.'
questions.explanation: Compound sentence with two independent clauses joined by 'but'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The book that I borrowed from the library is very interesting.'
questions.explanation: Complex sentence with a relative clause (that I borrowed from the library).

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'My grandfather takes a walk every morning.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with one subject and one finite verb.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Work hard, or you will fail.'
questions.explanation: Compound sentence with two clauses joined by 'or'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'If you study well, you will pass the exam.'
questions.explanation: Complex sentence with conditional clause (If you study well).

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The brave soldier fought courageously.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with one finite verb.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'He is poor, yet he is honest.'
questions.explanation: Compound sentence with two clauses joined by 'yet'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'I don't know where he lives.'
questions.explanation: Complex sentence with a noun clause (where he lives).

questions.question: Change to exclamatory: 'It was a beautiful sunset.'
questions.answer: What a beautiful sunset it was!

questions.question: Change to exclamatory: 'She sings very sweetly.'
Change to exclamatory: 'The rose is very beautiful.'
Change to exclamatory: 'He is a very clever boy.'
questions.answer: What a clever boy he is!

questions.question: Change to exclamatory: 'The match was exciting.'
questions.answer: What an exciting match it was!

questions.question: Change to assertive: 'What a magnificent palace it is!'
questions.answer: It is a very magnificent palace.

questions.question: Change to assertive: 'How beautifully she dances!'
Change to assertive: 'What a wonderful day it was!'
questions.answer: It was a very wonderful day.

questions.question: Change to assertive: 'How kind of you to help me!'
questions.answer: It is very kind of you to help me.

questions.question: Change to assertive: 'How I wish I could fly!'
Change to interrogative: 'Time is precious.'
Change to interrogative: 'Honesty is the best policy.'
Change to interrogative: 'No one can trust a liar.'
Change to interrogative: 'Nothing is impossible.'
Change to interrogative: 'Health is more important than wealth.'
questions.answer: Isn't health more important than wealth?

questions.question: Change to assertive: 'Can anyone deny his talent?'
questions.answer: No one can deny his talent.

questions.question: Change to assertive: 'Isn't she the best singer?'
Change to assertive: 'Who does not love his country?'
Change to assertive: 'Is there anything more precious than freedom?'
questions.answer: There is nothing more precious than freedom.

questions.question: Change to assertive: 'Can money buy happiness?'
Change simple to compound: 'Being tired, he went to bed early.'
questions.answer: He was tired, so he went to bed early.

questions.question: Change simple to compound: 'Besides being a doctor, he is also a writer.'
questions.answer: He is a doctor, and he is also a writer.

questions.question: Change simple to compound: 'Despite his wealth, he is unhappy.'
questions.answer: He is wealthy, yet he is unhappy.

questions.question: Change simple to compound: 'Work hard to succeed in life.'
questions.answer: Work hard, or you will not succeed in life.

questions.question: Change simple to compound: 'On seeing the police, the thief ran away.'
questions.answer: The thief saw the police, and he ran away.

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'I know his address.'
Change simple to complex: 'She is too weak to walk.'
questions.answer: She is so weak that she cannot walk.

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'He is a man of great honesty.'
questions.answer: He is a man who is very honest.

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'I expect to pass the exam.'
questions.answer: I expect that I will pass the exam.

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'The thief ran away on seeing the police.'
questions.answer: When the thief saw the police, he ran away.

questions.question: Change compound to simple: 'He is poor, but he is honest.'
questions.answer: In spite of being poor, he is honest.

questions.question: Change compound to simple: 'She worked hard, and she passed the exam.'
questions.answer: Working hard, she passed the exam.

questions.question: Change compound to simple: 'The sun set, and the birds returned to their nests.'
questions.answer: The sun having set, the birds returned to their nests.

questions.question: Change compound to simple: 'He opened the door and entered the room.'
questions.answer: Opening the door, he entered the room.

questions.question: Change compound to simple: 'Do your best, or you will regret it.'
questions.answer: Without doing your best, you will regret it.

questions.question: Change complex to simple: 'When I reached the station, the train had left.'
questions.answer: On reaching the station, I found the train had left.

questions.question: Change complex to simple: 'As he was ill, he could not attend school.'
questions.answer: Being ill, he could not attend school.

questions.question: Change complex to simple: 'I do not know where he lives.'
questions.answer: I do not know his address.

questions.question: Change complex to simple: 'If you work hard, you will succeed.'
Change complex to simple: 'The book that was written by Tagore is very famous.'
questions.answer: The book written by Tagore is very famous.
key_points: Relative clause becomes past participle phrase

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The patient who was admitted yesterday is recovering well.'
questions.explanation: Contains a relative clause 'who was admitted yesterday'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Finish your homework and go out to play.'
questions.explanation: Two imperative clauses joined by 'and'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Having completed his work, he went home.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with a perfect participial phrase.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Either you work hard or you will fail.'
questions.explanation: Two clauses joined by correlative conjunction 'either...or'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'I believe that he is innocent.'
questions.explanation: Contains a noun clause 'that he is innocent'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The boy standing near the gate is my brother.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with a present participial phrase.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'She is not only beautiful but also intelligent.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with correlative conjunction within one clause.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'He ran so fast that he won the race.'
questions.explanation: Contains an adverbial clause of result 'that he won the race'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The weather was bad, so the match was cancelled.'
questions.explanation: Two independent clauses joined by 'so'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'To err is human.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with infinitive as subject.

questions.question: Change to exclamatory: 'The scenery is very charming.'
Change to exclamatory: 'He gave a brilliant performance.'
questions.answer: What a brilliant performance he gave!

questions.question: Change to exclamatory: 'The baby is very cute.'
Change to exclamatory: 'It was a terrible accident.'
questions.answer: What a terrible accident it was!

questions.question: Change to exclamatory: 'The boy behaved very rudely.'
Change compound to complex: 'Work hard, or you will fail.'
questions.answer: If you do not work hard, you will fail.

questions.question: Change compound to complex: 'He is rich, but he is not happy.'
questions.answer: Although he is rich, he is not happy.

questions.question: Change compound to complex: 'Study well and you will pass.'
questions.answer: If you study well, you will pass.

questions.question: Change compound to complex: 'The bell rang and the students left.'
questions.answer: When the bell rang, the students left.

questions.question: Change compound to complex: 'He was poor but he was honest.'
questions.answer: Though he was poor, he was honest.

questions.question: Change complex to compound: 'As it was raining, I stayed at home.'
questions.answer: It was raining, so I stayed at home.

questions.question: Change complex to compound: 'Though he is poor, he is happy.'
questions.answer: He is poor, yet he is happy.

questions.question: Change complex to compound: 'If you work hard, you will succeed.'
questions.answer: Work hard, and you will succeed.

questions.question: Change complex to compound: 'When the sun set, we returned home.'
questions.answer: The sun set, and we returned home.

questions.question: Change complex to compound: 'Unless you study, you will fail.'
Identify the sentence type: 'Tell me the truth, and I will forgive you.'
questions.explanation: Imperative clause and declarative clause joined by 'and'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The man whom you met yesterday is my uncle.'
questions.explanation: Contains a relative clause 'whom you met yesterday'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'In spite of his poverty, he is generous.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with prepositional phrase.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'He fell ill; therefore, he could not attend.'
questions.explanation: Two independent clauses joined by 'therefore'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'I wonder if he will come.'
questions.explanation: Contains a noun clause 'if he will come'.

questions.question: Change to negative without changing meaning: 'He is as tall as his brother.'
questions.answer: He is not shorter than his brother.

questions.question: Change to negative without changing meaning: 'All students passed the exam.'
Change to affirmative: 'He is not less intelligent than his brother.'
questions.answer: He is as intelligent as his brother.

questions.question: Change to affirmative: 'Nobody was absent.'
Change to affirmative: 'No sooner did he arrive than it started raining.'
questions.answer: As soon as he arrived, it started raining.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Walk carefully lest you should fall.'
questions.explanation: Contains an adverbial clause of purpose with 'lest'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'He not only passed but also topped the class.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with correlative conjunction within one clause.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'I was so tired that I fell asleep.'
questions.explanation: Contains an adverbial clause of result.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Neither did he come nor did he call.'
questions.explanation: Two clauses joined by correlative conjunction 'neither...nor'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'We eat that we may live.'
questions.explanation: Contains an adverbial clause of purpose.

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'He admitted his guilt.'
questions.answer: He admitted that he was guilty.

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'I saw a wounded bird.'
questions.answer: I saw a bird which was wounded.

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'He worked hard to pass the exam.'
questions.answer: He worked hard so that he might pass the exam.
key_points: Infinitive of purpose becomes adverbial clause

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'Being intelligent, she topped the class.'
questions.answer: Because she was intelligent, she topped the class.

questions.question: Change simple to complex: 'Nobody can deny his success.'
questions.answer: Nobody can deny that he has succeeded.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The reason why he failed is known to all.'
questions.explanation: Contains an adverbial clause 'why he failed'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The sun rose and the fog disappeared.'
questions.explanation: Two independent clauses joined by 'and'.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'The teacher, along with the students, visited the museum.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with one finite verb despite multiple subjects.

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'He asked me where I lived.'
questions.explanation: Contains an indirect question (noun clause).

questions.question: Identify the sentence type: 'Neither the teacher nor the students were present.'
questions.explanation: Simple sentence with compound subject and one finite verb.
